title: Guardian naga

| **[Reference](/wiki/Source_code "Source code")**                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           | [monst.c#line1649](/wiki/Monst.c#line1649 "Monst.c")                                                                         |

A **guardian naga**, N, is a type of [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. It is an adult [naga](/wiki/Naga "Naga") that has the highest level, [speed](/wiki/Speed "Speed") and difficulty among its monster class, and is the only one to have three attacks.

A guardian naga has a [paralyzing](/wiki/Paralyzing "Paralyzing") bite attack, the ability to spit [blinding](/wiki/Blind "Blind") [venom](/wiki/Venom "Venom"), and a [holding attack](/wiki/Holding_attack "Holding attack") - the attack usually occurs as a touch attack, since it requires two prior melee attacks to grab you and guardian nagas will not typically use their venom attack in melee range. The attack still contributes to their experience reward, and they will use it in combat against other monsters. A guardian naga possesses [poison resistance](/wiki/Poison_resistance "Poison resistance").

A guardian naga [corpse](/wiki/Corpse "Corpse") is [poisonous](/wiki/Poisonous "Poisonous") to eat, but eating a guardian naga corpse or [tin](/wiki/Tin "Tin") has a 4⁄5 chance of conveying poison resistance.

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([NetHack 3.7.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.7.0 "NetHack 3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

Guardian nagas can use their hug attack, which is now an eel-style "wrap" attack. The attack cannot [drown](/wiki/Drown "Drown") you, as they cannot inhabit [pools](/wiki/Pool "Pool") or other bodies of water.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)
- [2 Strategy](#Strategy)
- [3 History](#History)
- [4 Origin](#Origin)
- [5 Variants](#Variants)
  - [5.1 dNetHack](#dNetHack)
- [6 Encyclopedia entry](#Encyclopedia_entry)
- [7 References](#References)

## Generation

Randomly generated guardian nagas may generate as peaceful towards lawful characters. A [guardian naga hatchling](/wiki/Guardian_naga_hatchling "Guardian naga hatchling") can [grow up](/wiki/Grow_up "Grow up") into a guardian naga.

Hostile guardian nagas can be generated via the [summon nasties](/wiki/Summon_nasties "Summon nasties") [monster spell](/wiki/Monster_spell "Monster spell").

The guardian naga is the second [quest](/wiki/Quest "Quest") monster for [Rogues](/wiki/Rogue "Rogue"), and make up 24⁄175 of the monsters randomly generated on the the [Rogue quest](/wiki/Rogue_quest "Rogue quest"). Several more guardian nagas are also generated on each level below the home floor at level creation: two are generated on each of the upper and lower filler levels, six are generated on the locate level, and eight are generated on the goal level. Guardian nagas also appear among the N that are part of the second quest monster class for Rogues, and make up 6⁄175 of the monsters randomly generated there.

The [Wizard of Yendor](/wiki/Wizard_of_Yendor "Wizard of Yendor") may create a clone of himself in the guise of a guardian naga via the [Double Trouble](/wiki/Double_Trouble "Double Trouble") [monster spell](/wiki/Monster_spell "Monster spell").[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

## Strategy

While technically not as dangerous as their [golden naga](/wiki/Golden_naga "Golden naga") cousins, guardian nagas quick and vicious foes whose paralyzing bite and 16 speed can prove [game-ending](/wiki/YASD "YASD") if you let yourself be surrounded by hostiles, or else are on the wrong end of a hostile lawful spellcaster's summoning. A [ring of free action](/wiki/Ring_of_free_action "Ring of free action") is very useful against them, especially if you lack ranged options to bring faraway ones down before they can close in - in the absence of the property or a spare [ring](/wiki/Ring "Ring") slot, [MC](/wiki/MC "MC")3 can suffice.

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([3.7.0](/wiki/3.7.0 "3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

[Orange dragon scales](/wiki/Orange_dragon_scales "Orange dragon scales") and [orange dragon scale mail](/wiki/Orange_dragon_scale_mail "Orange dragon scale mail") also confer [free action](/wiki/Free_action "Free action").

## History

The guradian naga first appears in [NetHack 3.0.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.0.0 "NetHack 3.0.0").

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Nāga](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/N%C4%81ga "wikipedia:Nāga")***

The Nāga (feminine "Nagi") are a supernatural race of half-human half-serpent beings that can occasionally take human form, and hold cultural significance in the folkloric traditions of many South Asian and Southeast Asian cultures over the past two millennia. Nagas also appear in *[Dungeons & Dragons](/wiki/Dungeons_%26_Dragons "Dungeons & Dragons")*.

Their most common depiction is that of a snake with a human head, which the default tileset of *NetHack* draws from—other iconographic depictions portray them as human from the waist up and snake from the waist down, wholly human with snakes on the heads and necks, or even as common serpents. Various south and southeastern Asian cultures also portray Nāgas as having multiple usually-serpentine heads.

## Variants

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack"), guardian nagas have a 2⁄5 chance of [generating with](/wiki/Monster_starting_inventory "Monster starting inventory") appropriately-sized [snakeleg](/index.php?title=Snakeleg\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Snakeleg (page does not exist)") [archaic plate mail](/index.php?title=Archaic_plate_mail\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Archaic plate mail (page does not exist)") and an [archaic helm](/index.php?title=Archaic_helm\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Archaic helm (page does not exist)").

A guaradian naga may be one of the monsters generated within a [magic item vault](/wiki/Special_room_\(dNetHack\)#Magic_item_vault "Special room (dNetHack)").

## Encyclopedia entry

The naga is a mystical creature with the body of a snake and the head of a man or woman. They will fiercely protect the territory they consider their own. Some nagas can be forced to serve as guardians by a spellcaster of great power.

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [src/wizard.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 50](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/wizard.c#L50)

[![This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.](/images/f/f7/Nh367-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.")

Guardian naga

From NetHackWiki

N guardian naga
Difficulty 16
Attacks Bite 1d6 paralysis, Spit 1d6 blinding venom, Hug 2d4
N guardian naga
Difficulty 16
Attacks

Bite 1d6 paralysis, Spit 1d6 blinding venom, Hug 2d4

Base level 12
Base experience 295
Speed 16
Base AC 0
Base MR 50
Alignment 7 (lawful)
Frequency (by normal means) 1 (Very rare)
Genocidable Yes
Weight 2600
Nutritional value 400
Size Huge
Resistances Poison
Resistances conveyed Poison (80%)

A guardian naga:

  • cannot pick up items.
  • has no limbs.
  • has a serpent body.
  • has a thick hide.
  • can lay eggs.
  • is poisonous to eat.
  • is omnivorous.
  • is strong.
Reference monst.c#line1649

A guardian naga, N, is a type of monster that appears in NetHack. It is an adult naga that has the highest level, speed and difficulty among its monster class, and is the only one to have three attacks.

A guardian naga has a paralyzing bite attack, the ability to spit blinding venom, and a holding attack - the attack usually occurs as a touch attack, since it requires two prior melee attacks to grab you and guardian nagas will not typically use their venom attack in melee range. The attack still contributes to their experience reward, and they will use it in combat against other monsters. A guardian naga possesses poison resistance.

A guardian naga corpse is poisonous to eat, but eating a guardian naga corpse or tin has a 4⁄5 chance of conveying poison resistance.

The following information pertains to an upcoming version (NetHack 3.7.0). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.

Guardian nagas can use their hug attack, which is now an eel-style "wrap" attack. The attack cannot drown you, as they cannot inhabit pools or other bodies of water.

Contents

  • 1 Generation
  • 2 Strategy
  • 3 History
  • 4 Origin
  • 5 Variants
    • 5.1 dNetHack
  • 6 Encyclopedia entry
  • 7 References

Generation

Randomly generated guardian nagas may generate as peaceful towards lawful characters. A guardian naga hatchling can grow up into a guardian naga.

Hostile guardian nagas can be generated via the summon nasties monster spell.

The guardian naga is the second quest monster for Rogues, and make up 24⁄175 of the monsters randomly generated on the the Rogue quest. Several more guardian nagas are also generated on each level below the home floor at level creation: two are generated on each of the upper and lower filler levels, six are generated on the locate level, and eight are generated on the goal level. Guardian nagas also appear among the N that are part of the second quest monster class for Rogues, and make up 6⁄175 of the monsters randomly generated there.

The Wizard of Yendor may create a clone of himself in the guise of a guardian naga via the Double Trouble monster spell.[1]

Strategy

While technically not as dangerous as their golden naga cousins, guardian nagas quick and vicious foes whose paralyzing bite and 16 speed can prove game-ending if you let yourself be surrounded by hostiles, or else are on the wrong end of a hostile lawful spellcaster's summoning. A ring of free action is very useful against them, especially if you lack ranged options to bring faraway ones down before they can close in - in the absence of the property or a spare ring slot, MC3 can suffice.

The following information pertains to an upcoming version (3.7.0). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.

Orange dragon scales and orange dragon scale mail also confer free action.

History

The guradian naga first appears in NetHack 3.0.0.

Origin

Wikipedia has an article about:
Nāga

The Nāga (feminine "Nagi") are a supernatural race of half-human half-serpent beings that can occasionally take human form, and hold cultural significance in the folkloric traditions of many South Asian and Southeast Asian cultures over the past two millennia. Nagas also appear in Dungeons & Dragons.

Their most common depiction is that of a snake with a human head, which the default tileset of NetHack draws from—other iconographic depictions portray them as human from the waist up and snake from the waist down, wholly human with snakes on the heads and necks, or even as common serpents. Various south and southeastern Asian cultures also portray Nāgas as having multiple usually-serpentine heads.

Variants

dNetHack

In dNetHack, guardian nagas have a 2⁄5 chance of generating with appropriately-sized snakeleg archaic plate mail and an archaic helm.

A guaradian naga may be one of the monsters generated within a magic item vault.

Encyclopedia entry

The naga is a mystical creature with the body of a snake and the head of a man or woman. They will fiercely protect the territory they consider their own. Some nagas can be forced to serve as guardians by a spellcaster of great power.


References

  1. ↑ src/wizard.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 50

A '''guardian naga''', {{monsym|guardian naga}}, is a type of [[monster]] that appears in ''[[NetHack]]''. It is an adult [[naga]] that has the highest level, [[speed]] and difficulty among its monster class, and is the only one to have three attacks.

A guardian naga has a [[paralyzing]] bite attack, the ability to spit [[blind]]ing [[venom]], and a [[holding attack]] - the attack usually occurs as a touch attack, since it requires two prior melee attacks to grab you and guardian nagas will not typically use their venom attack in melee range. The attack still contributes to their experience reward, and they will use it in combat against other monsters. A guardian naga possesses [[poison resistance]].

A guardian naga [[corpse]] is [[poisonous]] to eat, but eating a guardian naga corpse or [[tin]] has a {{frac|4|5}} chance of conveying poison resistance.

{{upcoming|NetHack 3.7.0|Guardian nagas can use their hug attack, which is now an eel-style "wrap" attack. The attack cannot [[drown]] you, as they cannot inhabit [[pool]]s or other bodies of water.}}

==Generation==
Randomly generated guardian nagas may generate as peaceful towards lawful characters. A [[guardian naga hatchling]] can [[grow up]] into a guardian naga.

Hostile guardian nagas can be generated via the [[summon nasties]] [[monster spell]].

The guardian naga is the second [[quest]] monster for [[Rogue]]s, and make up {{frac|24|175}} of the monsters randomly generated on the the [[Rogue quest]]. Several more guardian nagas are also generated on each level below the home floor at level creation: two are generated on each of the upper and lower filler levels, six are generated on the locate level, and eight are generated on the goal level. Guardian nagas also appear among the {{white|N}} that are part of the second quest monster class for Rogues, and make up {{frac|6|175}} of the monsters randomly generated there.

The [[Wizard of Yendor]] may create a clone of himself in the guise of a guardian naga via the [[Double Trouble]] [[monster spell]].{{refsrc|src/wizard.c|50|version=NetHack 3.6.7}}

==Strategy==
While technically not as dangerous as their [[golden naga]] cousins, guardian nagas quick and vicious foes whose paralyzing bite and 16 speed can prove [[YASD|game-ending]] if you let yourself be surrounded by hostiles, or else are on the wrong end of a hostile lawful spellcaster's summoning. A [[ring of free action]] is very useful against them, especially if you lack ranged options to bring faraway ones down before they can close in - in the absence of the property or a spare [[ring]] slot, [[MC]]3 can suffice.

{{upcoming|3.7.0|[[Orange dragon scales]] and [[orange dragon scale mail]] also confer [[free action]].}}

==History==
The guradian naga first appears in [[NetHack 3.0.0]].

==Origin==
{{Wikipedia|Nāga}}
The Nāga (feminine "Nagi") are a supernatural race of half-human half-serpent beings that can occasionally take human form, and hold cultural significance in the folkloric traditions of many South Asian and Southeast Asian cultures over the past two millennia. Nagas also appear in ''[[Dungeons & Dragons]]''.

Their most common depiction is that of a snake with a human head, which the default tileset of ''NetHack'' draws from—other iconographic depictions portray them as human from the waist up and snake from the waist down, wholly human with snakes on the heads and necks, or even as common serpents. Various south and southeastern Asian cultures also portray Nāgas as having multiple usually-serpentine heads.

==Variants==
===dNetHack===
In [[dNetHack]], guardian nagas have a {{frac|2|5}} chance of [[Monster starting inventory|generating with]] appropriately-sized [[snakeleg]] [[archaic plate mail]] and an [[archaic helm]].

A guaradian naga may be one of the monsters generated within a [[Special room (dNetHack)#Magic item vault|magic item vault]].

==Encyclopedia entry==
{{encyclopedia|<poem>
The naga is a mystical creature with the body of a snake and the head of a man or woman.  They will fiercely protect the territory they consider their own.  Some nagas can be forced to serve as guardians by a spellcaster of great power.
</poem>}}
